title: about
text:
Travelling is something we’ve always enjoyed. Whether it’s a quick weekend trip to a nearby town or a long journey to a distant country, it’s a chance to explore new places, meet new people, and learn more about the world.
So, what’s the subtitle of the website? It’s a quote from Jeff Tweedy, the front man of Wilco. He used it as the title of his memoir, “Let’s Go (So We Can Get Back): A Memoir of Recording and Discording with Wilco, Etc.” We totally get it. We love travelling, but there’s nothing quite like coming back home.

title: Pilgrimage (again)
text:
Crazy Horse Memorial


Our annual road trip in the summer of 2015.
First campsite in Princeton, BC:
First state in the trip:
Kootenai Falls, MT:
It was our third time at Beartooth Pass and this time we rode it in the opposite direction, from Montana to Wyoming.

Bike wash in Sheridan, WY:

Simply one of the best roads we’ve ridden, Bighorn Mountains, WY:
We rode 2829.2 km to get to South Dakota:
Spearfish Canyon, SD:
Deadwood, SD:


We saw some of the most beautiful looking bikes at Indian Campus in Sturgis, SD: 
This is the Chieftain with trunk:


Probably the worst hail storm we’ve ever experienced, luckily while having lunch in Sturgis, SD: 
Buffalo Chip in Sturgis, SD: 


The Crazy Horse Memorial, a mountain monument under construction on privately held land in the Black Hills, South Dakota, depicts the Oglala Lakota warrior Crazy Horse, riding a horse and pointing to his tribal land. Commissioned by Henry Standing Bear, a Lakota elder, it’s being sculpted by Korczak Ziolkowski. The Crazy Horse Memorial Foundation, a nonprofit organization, operates it. Construction began in 1948 and is ongoing.

Mount Rushmore:

Mount Rushmore, a sculpture of four American presidents, stands tall from left to right: George Washington, the first President of the United States and the inaugural president carved onto the mountain; Thomas Jefferson, the author of the Declaration of Independence and the driving force behind the Louisiana Purchase (1803); Theodore Roosevelt, the champion of the Square Deal; and Abraham Lincoln, whose leadership during the Civil War united America and led to the abolition of slavery.

Custer State Park, SD: 

Iron Mountain Road, SD: 
Riding into Badlands NP, SD: 


Devils Tower, WY: 

Camping in Dubois, WY: 
Grand Tetons, WY. This time we took an alternate road. 




History lessons in Cody, WY: 

Jackson, WY:

Ketchum, ID:

As always we stayed in 5-star accommodation, had great food and fine wine: 



And of course we rode so many great roads: 
Trip A:




 Back to top

title: Freewheelin’ Through the Land of Enchantment
text:
Our recent road trip through New Mexico was an unforgettable experience. After traversing 9,000 kilometres (5,600 miles) across eight states, we returned home on Canada Day safely and sound. The 22 days we spent on this adventure passed swiftly, yet we witnessed a plethora of captivating sights and were utterly enchanted by the state. Prior to embarking on this journey, New Mexico held a mystical allure for me, and that enchantment persists.
This time, our rides through Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Utah, Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, and Nevada were exceptional. The weather was remarkably dry, with occasional heatwaves.
Day 22 | WA and BC | 444 km

Breakfast at Super 8, Yakima, WA
Cherry stop at Prey’s fruit barn in Leavenworth, WA
Easy border crossing
Home around 7PM, safe and sound.
The end of 9,000 km trip and start of thinking about the next one.





 Back to top

title: The Grand Tour of the Western US
text:
Capitol Reef NP, UT





Nomad





Nomad





Four Corners





Avenue of the Giants in Redwoods NP, CA


We took the long way to Durango, Colorado, and got home on Saturday riding through Washington, Oregon, California, Nevada, Utah, Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado, Wyoming, Montana, and Idaho. We logged more than 8000 km or 5000 miles and visited many national and state parks:

Crater Lake NP, OR
Avenue of the Giants in Redwoods NP, CA
Lassen Volcanic NP, CA
Great Basin NP, NV
Capitol Reef NP, UT
Glen Canyon National Recreational Area, UT
Natural Bridges National Monument, UT
Valley of the Gods, UT
Monument Valley, UT and AZ
Four Corners Monument, UT, AZ, NM, CO
Arches NP, UT
Canyonlands NP (The Needles and Island in the Sky), UT
Dead Horse Point SP, UT

I was looking forward to crossing desert on the loneliest road in America, the famous US 50 in Nevada, and we were not disappointed. We also did HWY 93 in Idaho, from Bear Lake, UT, via Garden City, Montpelier, Pocatello, Atomic City, to Salmon (camped there) and Darby. It is the kind of ride you wish it never ended, but you either run out of daylight or run low on gas. Edith says she could ride it three times a year.
So many great roads, so many memories, and so many photos (we snapped around 2000 pix).

title: Olympic National Park, WA
text:
Our very first road trip on motorcycles was a memorable one. Many lessons were learned, and we had a lot of fun. We started in the early morning, excited and a bit nervous. The google maps was our guide, but we quickly realized that it wasn’t always reliable in remote areas.

title: Cardo G4 PowerSet Intercom Kit
text:
We bought this Bluetooth headset in early February, 2011 for $299.
We tried the intercom during our trip to the Black Hills, South Dakota. Initially, we were frustrated with the user manual and spent a few days fiddling around with the headsets before giving up. However, we tried them again and finally managed to chat!



Cardo G4

text:
Sundry statistics pertaining to this road trip:
• Most scenic freeway: I-84 from Pendleton to La Grande, OR • Most scenic byway: HWY 82 from La Grande to Joseph, OR • Most charming towns: Walla Walla, WA and Joseph, OR • Best hotel: Best Western*, Omak, WA • Best steak: Geiser Grand Restaurant, Baker City, OR • Best burger (ever): The Embers Brew House, Joseph, OR • Best pizza: Local Myth Pizza, Chelan, WA • Best brew: India Pale Ale, The Marc Restaurant, Walla Walla, WA • Best ice cream: Hought’s 24 Flavours, La Grande, OR • Best chiropractor: Steven Bachman, Baker City, OR • Highest elevation gained: 4310 ft. Wauconda Pass, WA • Longest distance ridden in a day: 440 miles • Shortest distance ridden in a day: 0 miles • Longest distance ridden in rain: 90 miles • Total distance ridden: 1740 miles

title: Big Sur
text:
Mount Rainier NP





Big Sur


After a year of hard work, my best friend and I embarked on a road trip to relax. Guided by two golden rules: take it easy and there are no rules, we were inspired by Jack Kerouac’s novels On the Road and Big Sur. We started our adventure in Mount Rainier National Park, Washington.
Last year, we visited Mount St. Helens, but Mount Rainier was hidden in the clouds, so we postponed our visit. This year, we were lucky and enjoyed the sunny skies. We visited two main attractions: Sunrise, at 6,400 feet, the highest point reachable by vehicle, and Paradise, famous for its glorious views and wildflower meadows. The roads to the visitor centres were good, and both locations were not crowded. We camped at The Dalles Campground on the banks of the White River, which was one of the best stays ever.
Riding into Oregon: Somehow we got disoriented after we left Mary’s Corner, WA, but a fellow H-D rider took us to the OR border on beautiful roads. Our first stop was in McMinnville, where we had a great lunch at Los Molcajetes (Sirloin steak burrito, probably one of the best).
McMinnville, OR
Salem, OR: We took some very enjoyable country roads into the state Capitol. Because it was late, we could see the building only from the outside. We camped at Silver Falls State Park, took an evening walk to the South Falls (177’) and saw the Winter, North and Upper North Falls the next day.
Mt. Angel, OR: We stopped at this Bavarian-styled town for breakfast and visited the Mount Angel Abbey, a very well-designed and maintained monastery; it was so peaceful there.
Cottage Grove, OR: We stopped here to see the covered bridges but were surprised by a vintage car show, Rock, Roll ’n Rumble. We saw the Centennial Bridge (1987), Stewart Bridge (1930) and Dorena Bridge (1949).
Gold Hill, OR: The stretch of I5 leading to this little town was very nice. We camped at KOA campground for two days to explore the area and ride the scenic byways. Rogue Creamery offers artisan blue cheeses and Lillie Belle Farms handmade chocolates, both establishments in Center Point, OR. We were not impressed by Medford but liked the old western town Jacksonville where we had lunch at Back Porch Bar & Grill (very good). We rode the Applegate Trail scenic byway to Murphy. Due to fires, there was a strong smell of smoke and the skies were hazy. We turned south to Ashland and enjoyed a walk and very good ice cream in this charming and expensive-looking town. On the way to KOA, we rode to Eagle Point and saw the Butte Creek Mill. It was a very enjoyable ride.
Riding into California: We took I5 to CA. Despite a road construction on the freeway, it was a very nice ride. Mt. Shasta was majestic! We stopped at the town of Mount Shasta for a healthy and delicious lunch. As soon as we saw the sign to Lake Shasta Caverns, we decided to check it out. The road there was twisty, there were some sudden 15 mph steep climbs and the road was quite narrow at some sections.
Next, we rode to Redding to see the Sundial Bridge. This modern glass-deck bridge crosses the Sacramento River:
After we left Redding, we were headed to Oroville to camp at KOA. We rode through some beautiful hazelnut and almond orchards; it was an enjoyable ride. But we found out that KOA Oroville was RVs only! Quite ticked off, we found a lonely campsite in that area and spent the night there.
Calistoga, CA:
Napa Valley and Sonoma:
V. Sattui Winery
Riding to San Francisco: Golden Gate Bridge
Watsonville, CA: Strawberries
Monterey, CA: Fisherman’s Wharf
Carmel-by-the-Sea, CA: B&B.
Big Sur: And we’re there.
San Luis Obispo, CA: Very nice town

title: Kona & Hilo
text: A wonderful vacation, relaxing and exciting. In the Pacific, relaxation was easy. And seeing wildlife, it was quite exciting: manta rays, dolphins, turtles, and wild goats roaming the lava fields. The black pepper plant and cocoa juice, made from cocoa seed pulp, were unforgettable.

title: Kona & Hilo

– Front 500 lbs. (226.8 kg)
– Rear 927 lbs. (420.5 kg)
Luggage Capacity
– Volume 2.26 cu. ft. (0.0633 m3)
Electric
Lights (as per country regulation), Indicator Lamps High beam, running lights, front fender running lights, directional light bar, neutral, low oil pressure, engine diagnostics, accessory, speakers, turn signals, security system (optional), 6-speed, low fuel warning, cruise control (optional), ABS (optiona
Gauges
Fairing-mounted electronic speedometer with odometer; time-of-day clock on CD player/stereo; dual trip meter; low fuel indicator light and mileage countdown feature; low oil pressure indicator light; engine diagnostics readout; LED indicator lights; 6-speed indicator light; tachometer with fuel, voltage, oil pressure and ambient air temperature gauges.

title: Canadian Rockies
text: A short road trip to the Canadian Rockies which includes a visit to the town of Banff, a ride along the Icefields Parkway, and a stop at Lake Louise is a perfect way to experience the stunning natural beauty of this region. Many memorable sights, from the turquoise waters of Lake Louise to the towering peaks of the surrounding mountains. We also visited Barkerville, a historic mining town in British Columbia, which provided a fascinating glimpse into the Gold Rush era.

title: Canadian Rockies

title: Canadian Rockies
text: Photos

title: Pilgrimage to the Black Hills and Badlands of ND and SD
text:
Here are the bullet points to our 7475 km journey to Sturgis, SD, and back home in the summer of 2011:

New pavement on the Crowsnest Highway between Hope and Manning Park, BC
Very nice scenic road between Princeton and Grand Forks, BC
Ice-cream break in historic Greenwood, BC, [the smallest city in Canada, is located on Highway #3 in the Kootenay Boundary region in southern BC. The hub of gold mining exploration in the Boundary, Greenwood was incorporated in 1897.]
Rode across Fernie, BC (Modern Alpine Resort town)
Saw the world’s biggest truck in Sparwood, BC
Crossed Crowsnest Pass, BC (no elevation sign, the lowest mountain pass in the Canadian Rockies)
Rode through Waterton Lakes National Park on a windy day [Where the Mountains Meet the Prairie: Rugged, windswept mountains rise abruptly out of gentle prairie grassland in spectacular Waterton Lakes National Park. Here, several different ecological regions meet and interact in a landscape shaped by wind, fire, flooding, and abundant plants and wildlife. The park helps protect the unique and unusually diverse physical, biological, and cultural resources found in the Crown of the Continent: one of the narrowest places in the Rocky Mountains from http://www.pc.gc.ca/pn-np/ab/waterton/index.aspx%5D.
Camped at Pitcher Creek, AB, survived a hailstorm
Rode the Fort Peck Dam spillway in Montana
Saw buffalo herds, feral [wild] horses, and prairie dogs up close in Theodore Roosevelt National Park in North Dakota
Took a guided tour of T. Roosevelt’s cabin in the Visitor Center.
Rode the scenic loop first clockwise and then the next day counterclockwise in Theodore Roosevelt National Park.
Beer and burger/pizza/salad at Boots Saloon & Grill in Medora, ND.
Scenic ride from Deadwood to Sturgis, SD via Silver City, Rapid City, and Nemo.
Visited Sturgis Motorcycle Museum, various street vendors, The Knuckle Saloon, and The Full Throttle Saloon.
Had beer in Saloon #10, which had many artifacts from the Wild Bill era, and a very good steak dinner at Frontier Steakhouse in Deadwood, SD.

title: Labour Day 2009 in WA
text:
Despite the weather forecasts, we bravely followed our long weekend plans. Only the first day was rainy, but we didn’t mind. You and your best friend, cruising along two great bikes through beautiful country—what more could you ask for?
Here are some of our highlights:

Passage through the North Cascades
Stay at the Best Western in Omak
The journey from Republic to Kettle Falls
Road along Roosevelt Lake
Grand Coulee Dam
Road along Banks Lake (we drove it three times and once before, for a total of four times)
Dry Falls
Mosses Lake
Pot Holes
Othello, with its many Mexican restaurants
I-90 through the Cascades
